findings.title: ST - Stops Transactions
findings.description: Initially, the contract does not allow the non-excluded addresses to transfer tokens.

findings.title: RCS - Redundant Conditional Statement
findings.description: The variable `tokenLiquidityThreshold` is always greater than 1, making the conditional statement redundant.

findings.title: PTRP - Potential Transfer Revert Propagation
findings.description: The contract sends funds to a `marketingWallet` and a `devWallet` as part of the transfer flow. These addresses can either be a wallet address or a contract. If the address belongs to a contract then it may revert from incoming payment. As a result, the error will propagate to the token’s contract and revert the transfer.

findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract is using variables that initialize them only in the constructor and are not defined as `immutable`.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure the value cannot be changed after it has been set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The code does not adhere to the Solidity naming conventions, which can lead to decreased readability and maintainability.

findings.title: L07 - Missing Events Arithmetic
findings.description: Events are a way to record and log information about changes or actions that occur within a contract.

findings.title: L13 - Divide before Multiply Operation
findings.description: Performing divisions before multiplications may cause loss of prediction.

findings.title: L14 - Uninitialized Variables in Local Scope
findings.description: Using an uninitialized local variable can lead to unpredictable behavior and potentially cause errors in the contract.

findings.title: L19 - Stable Compiler Version
findings.description: The `^` symbol indicates that any version of Solidity that is compatible with the specified version (i.e., any version that is a higher minor or patch version) can be used to compile the contract. The version lock is a mechanism that allows the author to specify a minimum version of the Solidity compiler that must be used to compile the contract code.

findings.title: L20 - Succeeded Transfer Check
findings.description: According to the ERC20 specification, the transfer methods should be checked if the result is successful. Otherwise, the contract may wrongly assume that the transfer has been established.
